content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to the standard galvanic cell represented in the diagram above. The reduction half-reactions for <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table below.

Half-Reaction
 <math alttext="E naught in volts"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>(V)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge plus 2 electrons produce C u solid"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Cu(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 0.34

<math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge plus 2 electrons produce Z n solid"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Zn(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="negative 0.76"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.76</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Write the net-ionic equation for the overall reaction that takes place as the cell operates.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to the standard galvanic cell represented in the diagram above. The reduction half-reactions for <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table below.

Half-Reaction
 <math alttext="E naught in volts"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>(V)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge plus 2 electrons produce C u solid"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Cu(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 0.34

<math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge plus 2 electrons produce Z n solid"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Zn(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="negative 0.76"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.76</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Write the net-ionic equation for the overall reaction that takes place as the cell operates.
(b) Calculate the value of <math alttext="E naught"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the cell.

(c) Calculate <math alttext="delta G naught"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole of reaction"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, for the cell.

(d) The following diagram on the left represents the copper nitrate solution in the half‑cell before the galvanic cell starts to operate. In the following diagram on the right, draw a representation of the solution in the same half‑cell after the galvanic cell has been operating for some time and is still producing a voltage.

(e) Assume that the mass of the <math alttext="C u "><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode changes by <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> grams in a certain period of time. Write a mathematical expression for the change in mass of the <math alttext="Z n"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode during the same period of time.

(f) For the standard cell, the <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> half-cell was made with <math alttext="1.0 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="1.0 molar C u open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cu(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> half-cell was made with <math alttext="1.0 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="1.0 molar Z n, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Zn(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The experiment was repeated, but this time the <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> half-cell was made with <math alttext="0.50 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="2.0 molar C u, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cu(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> half-cell was made with <math alttext="1.0 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="1.0 molar Z n, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Zn(NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the cell potential for the nonstandard cell greater than, less than, or equal to the value calculated in part <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(b)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

(g) If the experiment is repeated with the <math alttext="C u " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode replaced with a <math alttext="C u" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode with twice the mass, will the initial cell voltage be greater than, less than, or equal to the initial cell voltage in the original experiment? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
